thread.title_full: Modi faces heat over Tricolour autograph

author: New Delhi: Sep 26
title: Modi faces heat over Tricolour autograph
text:
Modi faces heat over Tricolour autograph New Delhi: Sep 26, 2015, DHNS & Agencies Govt says it was not the national flag
Prime Minister Narendra Modi was at the centre of another controversy as he put his signature on what appeared to be the Indian flag to be presented to US President Barack Obama.
Modi’s action was part of expressing gratitude to celebrity chef Vikas Khanna who had prepared a sumptuous spread for the dinner the prime minister hosted for top American CEOs in New York.
The Congress was quick to point out that Modi’s action amounted to violation of paragraph 3.28 of Section V of Part III of the Flag Code of 2002. It also did not miss out on the opportunity to remind Modi that the national flag was above the prime minister when it came to showing respect.
Government spokesman Frank Noronha denied that Modi had signed the national flag and said it had not been confiscated, as reported.
“The story about the prime minister disrespecting the Tricolour is false and mischievous. The prime minister did not autograph the tricolour,” Noronha, Principal Director General, Press Information Bureau, said.
He said the piece of cloth was a work of handicraft prepared by physically-challenged daughter of the chef and the prime minister had autographed it on compassionate basis after Khanna and his family made a request.
“The piece of cloth does not have white colour nor the wheel....It has been prepared by Khanna’s daughter with her toe and the prime minister was compassionate,” he said.
Congress, however, refused to be bogged down by the explanation. “We are not petty like BJP. We respect the office of the prime minister,” Randeep Singh Surjewala, in-charge of the AICC Communications Department told reporters here.
At the same time, he said the prime minister must look within and take corrective action as respect for the national flag is the responsibility of 125 crore people, more so for the prime minister.
